title: 113_hr4287
content: The "Independent Innovator and Repurposing Act" may extend the patent term for using biological products. The "Independent Innovator and Repurposing Act" allows for a 5-year extension of a patent for using biological products, provided certain conditions are met. The extension must be applied for by the patent owner before the original expiration date, and the patent must not have already expired or been extended through other means. To extend a patent for using biological products under the "Independent Innovator and Repurposing Act," the owner must submit an application to the Director with specific details including the identity of the product, patent, and claims, as well as proof of being an independent innovator or a qualified small business with ownership ties to the innovator. To extend a patent for using biological products under the "Independent Innovator and Repurposing Act," the applicant must meet specific criteria, including ownership ties to a qualified small business, filing a commercial marketing application, and a 10-year period between submitting an exemption application and FDA approval. The Food and Drug Administration approved the application for patent extension based on activities undertaken by the owner of record during the specified period. The Director determines patent eligibility solely based on the extension application representations. The Director shall issue a certificate of extension for 5 years if requirements are met. An interim extension of up to one year may be granted if the patent is eligible. Definitions are provided in this section. The Director can grant a patent extension for up to one year if eligible. Definitions for terms like "biological product" and "Director" are provided in this section. An "independent innovator" is defined as a person or entity not affiliated with the holder of a method of use patent for a biological product. A qualified small business, with fewer than 500 employees, is defined as an entity not affiliated with the holder of a marketing application approved for a biological product under the Public Health Service Act. The term "affiliated" includes relationships of employment, control, or common ownership, whether direct or indirect. A business with fewer than 500 employees, not affiliated with the holder of a marketing application for a biological product, is considered a qualified small business. This section will be effective upon the enactment of the Act and applies to any unexpired patent issued before or after that date.
